TopicTitle: What is the atmosphere density of the planets/laythe in KSP

Articles.Content: Does anyone know the atmosphere density of Kerbin, Duna, Eve, Jool & Laythe? Preferably expressed as grams/litre.

5.21 force field per decikerbal.

Ok cheers, Have you got a calculator that converts force-fields to grams, and decikerbals to litres?

Does anyone know the atmosphere density of Kerbin, Duna, Eve, Jool & Laythe? Preferably expressed as grams/litre.

The wiki does list some atmospheric characteristics and min/max temperatures.

I don't think there is anything directly that states humidity. Maybe there is a way to indirectly calculate atmosphere density with what is there?

http://wiki.kerbalspaceprogram.com/wiki/Laythe
We've been discussing the moisture content of Laythe's atmosphere here if needs be.

The game will tell you the pressure and the temperature at sea level. We also know the atmospheric scale heights independently. It has little information on composition though: we know only that Kerbin and Laythe have oxygen present (and can assume the former doesn't have so much that vegetation would all burn up), while Eve and Duna do not. You might try and estimate carbon dioxide levels by considering the greenhouse effect.
So, double post for an update: the Kerbal Engineer Redux reports atmospheric density. I don't know if it's a value from the game proper or something calculated by KER, but it's there.
"Atmospheric density" should be put in quotes, as that thing around planets in KSP got more in common with force fields than an atmosphere.
